metadata.title: [ML] Feature Transformation, NLP, and Classification Modeling on Hotel Scoring | by Tom Lin | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: [ML] Feature Transformation, NLP, and Classification Modeling on Hotel Scoring
metadata.description: Adopt a series of data visualization, feature transformation, word tokenization and machine learning/deep learning to build up a class model. Models being tested include MLP, Xgboost and Logistic.

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Introduction to Machine Learning with Python
Introduction to Machine Learning with Python
Exploring the use of XGBoost and its integration with Scikit-Learn
Feature Importance and Feature Selection With XGBoost in Python
How to Save Gradient Boosting Models with XGBoost in Python

all_paragraphs: The purpose of this post is that, in my prior attempt, I tried to build up a prediction model on reviewer’s score for each hotel. It turns out the predictive power is not satisfactory, with R² (Coefficient of Determination) lingers around 0.4 to 0.5. Thus in this task, I’m going to try a different path, in which I’ll first discretize the reviewer’s score into three ordinal categories — low, medium, high and then build up a classification model. See if it reaches higher predictive power under simplified classification method. It should be easier for the model to classify the reviewer’s score into three levels instead of requiring to come up with precise predicted score.

The original dataset is collected from Booking.com and shared on [Kaggle] platform. This dataset contains 500 thousands reviews for hotels and collects 14 features, including numerical scores and text reviews.

After comparing the performance of models among MLP, Xgboost, and Logistic, my final choice is Logistic Model. It turns out that Logistic Model not only outperforms than others, though only by a small margin, but also has rather excellent efficiency on training. Hyper-parameter fine tuning is also implemented in this task, but the result shows no significant performance difference between default configuration and optimized parameters setting.

The final model reaches 0.62 in accuracy and 0.61 in F1 score. If we look deeper, the share of each class are 35%, 29%, 36% in population, which compared to the Precision from the predicted result for each class being 68%, 47%, 65%, we can say that Logistic Model doubles the Precision generally.

In this section, the raw data will go through a series of preprocessing, so that to become quality, ready-for-use dataset. It includes implementation of missing values removal, duplicates removal, and outlier removal.
Explorative analysis includes statistical summary of target variable and all features. Visualize the data and observe how features are distributed.

After being more familiar with the data at hand, I will first divide target variable into three groups — low, medium, high. The range of each bin is customized based on the distribution of target variable, which, thus, has unequal bin widths.
4. Feature Engineering — Log Transformation

Shown from the distribution, the features are highly skewed. It’s better to use normal distributed features when feeding as inputs in the model. Thus, most numerical features will have log transformation and also be scaled to have the same unit, in preparation for modeling later on.
5. Feature Engineering — Word Tokenization

An upper-hand of this dataset is that it contains hotel guest’s text review along with their scoring. Hence, we can actually leverage the information provided from the text to increase prediction model’s accuracy. In this section, text will be preprocessed by lemmatisation and tokenization. Words are then assigned with values computed on TF-IDF formula.
In this part, I will check up if feature engineering increases the correlation between target variable(reviewer’s score) and input features. Results are shown in correlation matrix.

There are many models perfect for classification cases. Here, in my first attempt, I will compare performance of three modes — Logistic Regression, Xgboost Decision Tree, and Neural Network. Hyper-parameters are set as default.

From models above, the best performed model is chosen as the final one, and then model’s hyper-parameters will be fine tuned via grid search, so that to further increase its accuracy. The final model will be tested on testing dataset and compare to the default configured model.
︽ Dataset is checked if there exist any missing values or duplicates in rows. Uncompleted rows and duplicated rows are dropped off from dataset.
There are in total 3268 rows containing missing values and 526 duplicated rows. After removing them, the final dataset remains 511,944 records.
Interested in how data looks like, check up the link [Kaggle].
︽ In this section, there will be visualization on target variable and all other numerical features respectively.
Beforehand, I define a plotting function for the following visualization.
It’s obvious the distribution of reviewer’s score is left-skewed. There’s a huge share of scores spread around values 9.5 and above.

Following sets of grid chart show QQ-plot and histogram over each numerical features. QQ-plot increases readability to check if features follow normal distribution. In addition, there is an added line of theoretical normal distribution alongside kernel distribution for comparison on histograms. Below is the defined function to create QQ-plot and histogram side by side.

We can tell the almost all features are either left or right skewed except average score. With the evidence shown, these is in need for features transformation and normalization, so that the modeling can reach higher accuracy when using these features as inputs.
︽ Focused on target variable — reviewer_score, it will be divided into three groups. The bin interval are as follows,
After discretization, target variable is split into three groups of each share being 35%, 29%, 36% respectively.

︽ Numerical features are first log transformed and then scaled to be within range (0,1). This way, the numerical values will have the same unit with categorical features, which are also being on-hot encoded to (0,1) dummies later.
From the QQ-plots and histograms, we can tell that even after being transformed, features still don’t conform to normal distribution very well, but at least they are now less skewed.
︽ In cleaning up text data, I first concatenate the two separate reviews (one negative, one positive) into one, and then have it stripped off white space and other punctuations.
Before tokenizing text, I use lemmatizer to further extract the root of each words, so that trimming away the derivations of words in different forms.
Then the stop words are neglected and to specify word selection threshold by max_df and min_df.
Bi-gram is used in tokenization, so that we get to take into account the opposite meaning in phrases, such as very good and not good.
First 2500 tokens are selected to be model inputs afterwards.

︽ Down below, I will present the correlation between target (reviewer_score) and all other features, including both before and after feature transformation. To see if the correlation is amplified because of the transformation or remains the same.
Observing the correlation, I come to some interesting findings.
︽ Now comes the key part of whole task — modeling. I will first experiment on three different models, Multi-Perceptron, Xgboost, and Logistic Regression.

These models will be compared based on their performance (F1 score) on test dataset. The best model will be carried on to the next section, that is hyper-parameter fine tuning. So that we can further improve its accuracy.

In fitting a Xgboost model, we receive extra perks out of it. Xgboost can provide us plot of feature importance, so that we can tell actually what features are more informative and influential to classify the data.
Quick ranking here, we can tell from the feature importance plot (Xgboost) that the first 5 important features being identified are,

One thing worth noted, here I chose to use both uni-gram and bi-gram as input features, and it seems most important tokens are uni-gram, not a single bi-gram ranked in the first 20 important features.

It turns out that Logistic Regression reaches the best performance (F1 score) on testing dataset, though only by a small margin. But taking into account its training efficiency on such large amount of data and features (more than 2000 features), this is truly impressive.

Hence, in the following section, I will further fine tune hyper-parameters on Logistic Regression. But generally speaking, three models all perform pretty well in classifying the dataset with all accuracy above 60%, comparing to random guess where the accuracy would be around 33%, that’s quite a predictive power gain. More details are listed at the table below.
︽ In this section, I will further fine tune logistic model’s hyper-parameters, and see if it increases model’s performance even more.
The hyper-parameters being fine tuned (grid search) are C and penalty. These two parameters are both in charge of model’s regularization.
We can even better grasp the whole performance over different combinations of hyper-parameters via heat map visualization. Let’s see chart down below.
The function for plotting grid search scores in heatmap is referred from Introduction to Machine Learning with Python, the must-have ML book for beginners.
The best parameters being chosen is 0.5 for C and L1 for penalty.
It seems once C goes beyond 0.5, the performance of the model reaches plateau. No more accuracy improved.
Furthermore, it seems the benefits gained from fine tuning is marginal, no significant improvement there. As most scores in upper-right remain 0.61 consistently.
Now, let’s check up how much improvement it gains with versus without hyper-parameters fine tuning.

After all the effort of cleaning, transforming, training, and fine tuning classification model on reviewer’s scoring. The model performs pretty well on identifying low and high scores but not so well on scores in the middle.
See the Recall, the model can only actually identify 31% of all scores in medium, meaning the rest 69% are being mis-classified as either low or high level.

Nonetheless, if we look at the Precision, then at least model reaches 47% of accuracy, meaning for every sample that’s being labeled as medium, there is 47% percent chance of being correct. Comparing to random guess, which would be 29%. It is still considered a significant gain.
The comprehensive jupyter notebook can be found in this link: [Github]. If you enjoy this post, welcome to leave your feedback down below. Let’s improve this model even better together!!!
[2] A. Muller, Introduction to Machine Learning with Python (2018), github
[3] S. Hallows, Exploring the use of XGBoost and its integration with Scikit-Learn (2018), kaggle
[5] J. Brownlee, Feature Importance and Feature Selection With XGBoost in Python (2016), Machine Learning Mastery
[6] J. Brownlee, How to Save Gradient Boosting Models with XGBoost in Python (2016), Machine Learning Mastery
An enthusiastic in swimming, jogging and movies besides my job as an analyst. Specifically with long-standing passion on customer behavior analysis.
